This appendix contains a list of books and online resources on various C++-related topics that were either consulted while writing this book, or are recommended for further or background reading

note: This book assumes no previous programming experience, but even so, it is also a good read for experienced programmers.
title: Beginning C++ Without Previous Programming Experience ➤➤ Bjarne Stroustrup. Programming: Principles and Practice Using C++
ISBN: 0-321-99278-4. An introduction to programming in C++ by the inventor of the language

note: ISBN: 0-596-00419-2. An introductory C++ text that assumes no prior programming experience.
title: Practical C++ Programming

note: ISBN: 0-133-59174-3. Assumes no prior programming experience. This book is often used as a textbook in introductory programming courses.
title: Problem Solving with C++
ISBN: 0-321-71411-3. A very thorough introduction to C++ that covers just about everything in the language in a very accessible format and in great detail

note: ISBN: 0-201-70353-X. Covers the same material as C++ Primer, but in much less space, because it assumes that the reader has programmed in another language before.
title: Accelerated C++: Practical Programming by Example
More Exceptional C++: 40 New Engineering Puzzles, Programming Problems, and Solutions

ISBN: 0-201-70434-X. Covers additional exception safety topics not covered in Exceptional C++: 47 Engineering Puzzles, Programming Problems, and Solutions. This book also discusses effective objectoriented programming and correct use of certain aspects of the Standard Library
Exceptional C++ Style: 40 New Engineering Puzzles, Programming Problems, and Solutions

ISBN: 0-201-76042-8. Discusses generic programming, optimization, and resource management. This book also has an excellent exposition of how to write modular code in C++ by using nonmember functions and the single responsibility principle

note: ISBN: 0-321-12518-5. Provides 99 specific tips for C++ programming.
title: C++ Gotchas: Avoiding Common Problems in Coding and Design

note: ISBN: 0-130-35313-2. The second volume of Eckel’s book, which covers more advanced C++ topics. The text is also available at no cost online at www.bruceeckel.com.
title: Thinking in C++
C++ in a Nutshell
ISBN: 0-596-00298-X. A C++ reference covering everything from the basics to more-advanced material

note: ➤➤ The C++ Reference, at www.cppreference.com. An excellent reference of C++98, C++03, C++11, C++14, and C++17.
title: ISBN: 0-321-77640-2. One of the most comprehensive C++ books available
A website containing a lot of information related to C++, with a complete reference of the language, including C++17

author.literal: The C++ Standard Library ➤➤ Peter Van Weert and Marc Gregoire.
C++ Standard Library ➤➤ Nicolai M. Josuttis.
C++ Standard Library. ➤➤ David R. Musser, Gillmer J. Derge, and Atul Saini.

container-title: ➤➤ Stephan T. Lavavej. Standard Template Library (STL
Shows/Going+Deep/C9-Lectures-Introduction-to-STL-with-Stephan-T-Lavavej. An interesting video lecture series on the
drdobbs.com/cpp/184403853. An excellent explanation of making function templates friends of classes
note: ➤➤ David Vandevoorde, Nicolai M. Josuttis, and Douglas Gregor. C++ Templates: The Complete Guide,

ISBN: 0-321-71412-1. Everything you ever wanted to know (or didn’t want to know) about C++ templates. This book assumes significant background in general C++. ➤➤ David Abrahams and Aleksey Gurtovoy. C++ Template Metaprogramming: Concepts,
title: C++ Standard Library Quick Reference
ISBN: 978-1-4842-1875-4. This quick reference is a condensed guide to all essential data structures, algorithms, and functions provided by the
The C++ Standard Library: A Tutorial and Reference

ISBN: 0-321-62321-5. Covers the entire Standard Library, including I/O streams and strings as well as the containers and algorithms. This book is an excellent reference. ➤➤ Scott Meyers. Effective STL: 50 Specific Ways to Improve Your Use of the Standard Template Library
ISBN: 0-201-74962-9. Written in the same spirit as the author’s Effective C++ books. This book provides targeted tips for using the Standard Library, but is not a reference or tutorial
STL Tutorial and Reference Guide: Programming with the Standard Template Library

ISBN: 0-321-70212-3. Similar to the Josuttis text, but covering only parts of the Standard Library, such as containers and algorithms. Unified Modeling Language ❘ 1067 C++ Templates ➤➤ Herb Sutter. “Sutter’s Mill: Befriending Templates
Tools, and Techniques from Boost and Beyond
Delivers practical metaprogramming tools and techniques into the hands of the everyday programmer

author.literal: ALGORITHMS AND DATA STRUCTURES ➤➤ Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein.

container-title: Mastering Algorithms with C: Useful Techniques from Sorting to Encryption. O’Reilly Media, 1999. ISBN: 1-565-92453-3. An approachable reference to data structures and algorithms. RANDOM NUMBERS ➤➤ Eric Bach and Jeffrey Shallit. Algorithmic Number Theory, Efficient Algorithms
note: ISBN: 0-262-02405-5. ➤➤ Oded Goldreich. Modern Cryptography, Probabilistic Proofs and Pseudorandomness.
title: Introduction to Algorithms
ISBN: 0-262-03384-4. One of the most popular introductory algorithms books, covering all the common data structures and algorithms
The Art of Computer Programming Volume 1: Fundamental Algorithms
The Art of Computer Programming Volume 2: Seminumerical Algorithms
The Art of Computer Programming Volume 3: Sorting and Searching
The Art of Computer Programming Volume 4A: Combinatorial Algorithms, Part 1

ISBN: 0-201-03804-8. Knuth’s four-volume tome on algorithms and data structures. If you enjoy mathematical rigor, there is no better text on this topic. However, it is probably inaccessible without undergraduate knowledge of mathematics or theoretical computer science. ➤➤ Kyle Loudon
ISBN: 3-642-08432-X. Two books that explain the theory of computational pseudo-randomness
A mathematical explanation of the Mersenne Twister, used to generate pseudo-random numbers
➤➤ The Open Source Initiative at www.opensource.org

➤➤ The GNU Operating System—Free Software Foundation at www.gnu.org. Websites where the two main open-source movements explain their philosophies and provide information about obtaining open-source software and contributing to its development

author.literal: SOFTWARE ENGINEERING METHODOLOGY ➤➤ Robert C. Martin.

container-title: ➤➤ Mike Cohn. Succeeding with Agile: Software Development Using Scrum
note: ISBN: 0-321-57936-4. An excellent guide to start with the Scrum methodology.
title: Agile Software Development, Principles, Patterns, and Practices

ISBN: 978-1292025940. Written for software engineers “in the trenches,” this text focuses on the technology—the principles, patterns, and process—that help software engineers effectively manage increasingly complex operating systems and applications
The Pragmatic Programmer

ISBN: 978-0201616224. A classic book, and a must read for every software engineer. Almost twenty years later, its advice is still spot on. It examines the core process—what do you do, as an individual and as a team, if you want to create software that’s easy to work with and good for your users
A Spiral Model of Software Development and Enhancement
A landmark paper that described the state of software development at the time and proposed the Spiral Model
Extreme Programming Explained: Embrace Change
ISBN: 0-321-27865-8. One of several books in a series that promote Extreme Programming as a new approach to software development
Quality Software Project Management
ISBN: 0-130-91297-2. A guidebook for anybody who is responsible for the management of software development processes
Facts and Fallacies of Software Engineering
ISBN: 0-321-11742-5. Discusses various aspects of the software development process and exposes hidden truisms along the way
The Rational Unified Process: An Introduction
ISBN: 0-321-19770-4. Provides an overview of RUP, including its mission and processes
Death March
ISBN: 0-131-43635-X. A wonderfully enlightening book about the politics and realities of software development
A detailed discussion of the Scrum methodology. ➤➤ Manifesto for Agile Software Development
The complete Agile software development manifesto. ➤➤ Wikipedia
Explains the concepts behind revision control systems, and what kinds of solutions are available

author.literal: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE ➤➤ David A. Patterson and John L. Hennessy.

container-title: EFFICIENCY ➤➤ Dov Bulka and David Mayhew
title: Computer Organization and Design: The Hardware/Software Interface
Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach
ISBN: 0-123-83872-X. Two books that provide all the information most software engineers will ever need to know about computer architecture
One of the few books to focus exclusively on efficient C++ programming. This book covers both language-level and design-level efficiency
Information about the gprof profiling tool
Effective Software Testing: 50 Specific Ways to Improve Your Testing
ISBN: 0-201-79429-2. A book aimed at quality assurance professionals, although any software engineer will benefit from this book’s discussion of the software-testing process

author.literal: DESIGN PATTERNS ➤➤ Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides.

note: ➤➤ Wikipedia. Software design pattern. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ Design_pattern_(computer_science). Contains descriptions of a large number of design patterns used in computer programming. Multithreaded Programming ❘ 1073
title: Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software

ISBN: 0-201-63361-2. Called the “Gang of Four” (GoF) book (because of its four authors), the seminal work on design patterns. ➤➤ Andrei Alexandrescu. Modern C++ Design: Generic Programming and Design Patterns Applied
ISBN: 0-201-70431-5. Offers an approach to C++ programming that employs highly reusable code and patterns. ➤➤ John Vlissides. Pattern Hatching: Design Patterns Applied
ISBN: 0-201-43293-5. A companion to the GoF book, explaining how patterns can actually be applied
Head First Design Patterns
ISBN: 0-596-00712-4. A book that goes further than just listing design patterns. The authors show good and bad examples of using patterns, and give solid reasoning behind each pattern

container-title: ➤➤ Maurice Herlihy and Nir Shavit. The Art of Multiprocessor Programming
note: ISBN: 0-123-97337-6. A great book on writing code for multiprocessor and multicore systems.
title: C++ Concurrency in Action: Practical Multithreading

ISBN: 1-933-98877-0. An excellent book on practical multithreaded programming, including the C++ threading library. ➤➤ Cameron Hughes and Tracey Hughes. Professional Multicore Programming: Design and Implementation for C++ Developers
ISBN: 0-470-28962-7. A book for developers of various skill levels who are making the move into multicore programming
